Chapter 5
Ch 5.1 Continuous Function
Ch 5.3 Continuous Functions on Intervals

Let \(a < b < c\). Suppose that \(f\) is continuous on \([a, b]\), that \(g\) is continuous on \([b, c]\), and that \(f(b) = g(b)\). Define \(h\) on \([a,c]\) by \(h(x) := f(x)\) for \(x \in [a, b]\) and \(h(x) = := g(x)\) for \(x \in [b,c]\). Prove that \(h\) is continuous on \([a, c]\)
Answer
Preliminary Analysis
Notice that \(h(x) = \begin{cases}
    f(x) & x \in [a,b] \\
    g(x) & x \in [b,c]
\end{cases}\). Thus for \([a,b]\), \(h\) continuous because \(f\) continuous, and for \([b,c]\), \(h\) continuous because \(g\) continuous. and because \(f(b) = g(b)\), then it follows that \(h(b) = f(b) = g(b)\) which implies that \(h\) continuous at \(x = b\). Therefore \(h\) continuous on \([a,c]\) \
Formal Proof
\(h\) continuous on \([a,c]\) because \(h\) continuous on \([a,b]\) and \([b,c]\)
